Emergency resource Dr. Samuel parker Central park hospital (804)0938172 988 Suicide & crisis lifeline Call or text 988 or chat 988lifeline.org. The 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline is a national network of local crisis centers that provides free and confidential emotional support to people in suicidal crisis or emotional distress 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Disaster distress helpline The national Disaster Distress Helpline is available for anyone experiencing emotional distress related to natural or human-caused disasters.Call or text 1-800-985-5990 to be connected to a trained, caring counselor, 24/7/365.
Crisis text line Text MHA to 741741 and you\'ll be connected to a trained Crisis Counselor. Crisis Text Line provides free, text-based support 24/7. The trevor project
Call 1-866-488-7386 or text START to 678678.A national 24-hour, toll free confidential suicide hotline for LGBTQ youth.
Trans lifeline Dial 877-565-8860 for US and 877-330-6366 for Canada.Trans Lifeline\'s Hotline is a peer support service run by trans people, for trans and questioning callers.

Get yourself out of “fast pace cycle We are all stressed out… Most of us work too much, schedule too much, and hear about too many negative events in the world. Sometimes, you can’t avoid any of it. Here’s your first task on your journey toward peace of mind: Choose a time and place to devote to this mental wellness discovery.. What should you do during these 15 minutes? During this course, you’ll be given lots of positive and productive things to think about. During each 15 minute session, set a timer on your phone so you can responsibly disconnect from the other things you might have scheduled. In your mind, shut the door on all the noisy thoughts you may be used to and enjoy the time you’ve dedicated toward improving your mental health. Make sure to set a reminder for the time and place you specified above.
Set reminder: Set timer: Other? Write a place
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems? Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems? Do you enjoy a drink now and then\nMany of us do, often when socializing with friends and family. Lets take a look at your drinking patterns and how they may affect your health.\nThe AUDIT questionnaire is designed to help in the self-assessment of alcohol consumption and to identify any implications for the persons health and well being, now and in the future. Drug use refers to the use of prescribed or over‐the‐counter drugs in excess of the directions, and any non medical use of drugs. \nThe various classes of drugs may include cannabis , solvents , tranquilizers, barbiturates, cocaine, stimulants, hallucinogens or narcotics . The questions do not include alcoholic beverages.\nPlease answer every question. If you have difficulty with a statement, then choose the response that is mostly right.
Afternoon Add time & alarm Did you know? What is anxiety? Let\'s begin! Are you ready? The Calmscient discovery will only be as effective as you make it. \nSo be determined to dedicate time to following along and completing the exercises. Each section has interesting and informative content that is designed to keep you actively thinking about your specific challenges. But, like taking a road trip to an unknown destination, you’ll need to be committed to following the map! It may be a little more work than you’re used to, but it will absolutely pay off in the end. If a person could simply “remember” past experiences,
Anxiety is a normal brain response to stress. The Fight, Flight, and Freeze responses help us meet the demands of potential threats. Things that can cause anxiety are:
\n • Encountering past threats\n • Unknown risks, changes, or results\n • Lack of skill or support\n Our nervous system is not broken! Learning to control it is an important and powerful skill we can master in order to keep stressful situations in their place.
Do you remember our road trip plan? You may not have noticed, but we’re already on STEP 4! Congratulations on getting this far. We’ve now arrived at some practical skills you can learn to influence your body to calm down.
Our brain is like a computer. It has a basic operating system that helps us deal with the normal, day-to-day tasks and complexities of life. But when it detects a threat that can interrupt or damage normal operation, an alarm activates that immediately alerts us to the danger.\n\n You can imagine why this “Threat Alert” in our nervous system always takes priority. It’s so that we can get back to normal operations as quickly as possible. When this threat system is triggered, stress responses such as Fight/Flight/Freeze are activated. Stress hormones, such as adrenaline and cortisol, flood our system in order to meet the demands of the danger. Intense emotions, such as anxiety, fear and feeling overwhelmed, can overtake our mind.\n\n Understandably, general brain functions slow down or may be put “on hold” until the danger is taken care of. This is why we might feel that our thinking capacity diminishes when we are experiencing anxiety. Our “Threat Alert” system is an important part of our brain function, but when it is constantly engaged, enjoying life or having a full sense of self becomes difficult and may even feel out of reach.\n\n What are some things that can activate our “Threat Alert” system? They can be:\n …the thought that we might encounter situations or people that threatened us in the past.\n …unknown risks, unknown changes or unknown results when making a decision.\n …facing a challenging situation that we don’t think we have enough skills or support to overcome.\n\n Remember: anxiety is a normal brain response to stress. Our nervous system is not broken and there is nothing wrong with us when we feel anxious! Learning to control it is an important and powerful skill we can master in order to keep stressful situations in their place.\n
A calm mind can only start with a calm body. Why is that?\n\n Remember: anxiety is our body’s response to danger, whether real or imagined. So if we can control our body, we can suppress our mind from responding with overwhelming worry and rumination.\n\n The very beginning of anxiety starts with “body sensations”. As soon as we perceive them, we will learn to “press pause”, so to speak. Our goal is to lower our stress hormones and this will result in stabilizing our nervous system.\n Some of the best techniques include exercises for mindful breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, body movement and resource installation.\n\n These exercises will calm your stress response and give you the space to handle anxious thoughts and build healthy behaviors. This will result in physical and emotional betterment.\n\n Why don’t you practice some of these exercises for ten minutes every morning or right before bedtime? The key is consistency so that your body learns what it feels like to have a calm nervous system.\n\n
Mindfulness – what is it? Touch and the butterfly hug Hand over your heart Mindful walking Movement: dance Movement: running Mindful body movement Deep breathing Progressive muscle relaxation
Have you ever caught your mind wandering or daydreaming while you are in the middle of a familiar or repetitive task? You could be walking, working or even driving your car, and your mind is miles away, perhaps fantasizing about going on vacation, thinking about your to-do list, or worrying about some upcoming event. In either case, you are not focusing on the current situation and not in touch with the ‘here and now’. This mode of operation is often referred to as automatic pilot. Mindfulness is the opposite of automatic pilot. It is about experiencing the world that is firmly in the ‘here and now’. This is referred to as the being mode. It liberates you from automatic and unhelpful thoughts and responses. How does mindfulness help with anxiety? When we allow our brain to enter automatic pilot mode too often, it can be at risk of being conditioned to be overly preoccupied about the future, past experiences or our emotions in negative ways. If we have fallen into this old and unhelpful habit, we can unlearn it and replace it with skills that help us resist ‘buying into’ automatic worry and anxiety. Mindfulness reminds us that we don’t have to take immediate control of, remove or fix unpleasant experiences. Instead, we can identify and actively engage in something that will give us a sense of safety and connection. As a simple example: Instead of focusing on how many miles you walked in the morning, can you be mindfully aware of the birds singing, actively feel the fresh air, and sense the changing of the season? When you connect your senses to nature, animals, people and your own body, you capture the attention of your nervous system, which in turn soothes your anxiety. When you return home, you will be in a better frame of mind and more prepared to face your day. Which mindfulness exercises would you like to make part of your daily routine? Calmscient can remind you of some easy mindfulness routines that will help you stay in a healthy, being mode.
Humans respond powerfully to touch. Gentle, affectionate touch helps calm the nervous system and can trigger the release of oxytocin, the attachment hormone. Interestingly, when it comes to releasing oxytocin, our bodies don’t differentiate between the touch of a loved one or our own touch as we hold ourselves.\n When you are feeling upset, ungrounded, agitated or irritable, try giving yourself a hug or a gentle stroke on the cheek and see how it impacts the way you feel. Interlock your thumbs to form a butterfly shape Place both hands over your chest, and alternate tapping your middle finger just below your collarbone Breathe slowly and deeply (abdominal breathing) while you mentally observe what is going through your mind and body—thoughts, images, sounds, odors, feelings, and physical sensation.
Hand over your heart How to do it • Rest the heel of your hand on your sternum around your heart area.
\n • Apply a steady, gentle, but firm pressure.
\n • For added effect, you can place your other hand across your forehead or on your abdomen.
\n • Experiment with the various placements and wait until you feel a shift. It may take up to 5 or 10 minutes of deep breathing in this position to shift if you are very activated.
Movement: dance Moving your body to music can be a fun and fast way to shift your state and reconnect with your body, rhythm and expression.
There are many movement routines that invite you to reconnect with your body. Pilates, yoga and other similar stretching exercises incorporate mindful awareness of movements and postures. Additionally, coordinating body movement and breath further potentiates your ability to shift your state.
Find a comfortable and quiet place to sit or lie down. You can also practice deep breathing while standing, but ensure you have proper balance and support.
Did you know? An estimated 31.1% of U.S. adults experience any anxiety disorder at some time in their lives. You’re not alone!
What is anxiety? Simply put, Anxiety is a helpful survival mechanism Imagine an early human trying to survive out in the woods. As in most forms of life, several built-in survival mechanisms are passed along from one generation to the next through DNA, and are an important part of the survival of a species.
Some of the responses to this survival mechanism are: FIGHT Face the threat head on!
FIGHT Look for a way out!
FREEZE Can’t move!
But now imagine this person coming face-to-face with a hungry bear. Fight, Flight, or Freeze may not be enough to survive this encounter! A bear is much stronger, faster, and smarter for either of those responses. This is where the “Worry” survival mechanism comes into play.
If a person could simply “remember” past experiences, “Worry” could help them take measures to avoid or back away from dangers before they became life threatening. In this example, if the person spotted a hungry bear from a distance, they would remember the potential danger and take another route, or possibly remember and avoid the places where bears were actively hunting for food. In both cases, “Worry” would help them survive successfully. So, worrying is a helpful skill!
But how does too much “Worry” affect us? We often called this excess of worry “Anxiety”.
In our modern world, there are many bear-like situations we face every day. It’s easy to become conditioned to constantly trigger our “Worry” response in order to avoid the need to “Fight, Flight or Freeze”.\n\nBut overprotecting ourselves with anxiety often comes at the expense of our happiness. Excessive use of worry, rumination, or fear of being at the wrong place at the wrong time limits our ability to enjoy life.
Remember: worry and anxiety are not your enemies! The key to more peace of mind lies in enhancing your understanding of both and then learning the skills to use them in the right moments and for the right amounts of time.
We are all stressed out… Most of us work too much, schedule too much, and hear about too many negative events in the world. Sometimes, you can’t avoid any of it. Here’s your first task on your journey toward peace of mind:
You’re looking for only 15 minutes a day to methodically progress through the Calmscient courses… When is a good time for you? Great! You’ve taken some positive action, and that’s a bigger deal than you might think.
What should you do during these 15 minutes? During this course, you’ll be given lots of positive and productive things to think about. During each 15 minute session, set a timer on your phone so you can responsibly disconnect from the other things you might have scheduled. In your mind, shut the door on all the noisy thoughts you may be used to and enjoy the time you’ve dedicated toward improving your mental health. Make sure to set a reminder for the time and place you specified above.
Making a plan to tackle anxiety is like mapping a route to a destination. Seeing the whole journey at a glance can help you visualize your trip and be confident in how you will get there. Once the route is set, you know you’ll arrive if you follow all the indicated turns and directions. There will be fewer surprises and you will feel more in control.
When faced with a situation that causes you anxiety, imagine that the “destination” is the other side of that stressful situation. Here is how navigating that stressful situation might look like:
STEP 1 Be aware of what’s around you Take note of how your anxiety is impacting your emotions, choices and decisions. \n\nChange your thinking from: “Something must be wrong with me” to: “I just need to protect myself from my environment which is filled with anxiety-inducing things”.
STEP 2 Spot your anxiety triggers Take note of which specific situations, thoughts or feelings trigger your anxiety and even write them down somewhere. Where possible, this will help you take action to avoid anxiety-inducing situations and learn to manage the ones you have no control over.
STEP 3 Remember that you are not an anxious person Learn to identify the three components of anxiety: Physiological (Body), Cognitive (Mind) and Behavioral (Actions). This will help to follow action plans that calm your mind, body and actions.
STEP 4 Implement body calming skills You can learn to force your body to calm down. Once your body is calm, your mind will follow. Skills such as relaxation, progressive muscle relaxation, mindful breathing and walking will become second nature.
STEP 5 Set a mental boundary between you and your worries There are ways to “delay” your worry until a designated “worry time” so you can focus on your daily routine without fearing that important things will be dropped.
STEP 6 Implement mind calming skills Biased thinking (Cognitive Distortion) greatly affects our tendency to worry irrationally and causes persistent anxiety. This happens when, based on past experiences, we either underestimate or overestimate the stressors of a particular situation without looking at them realistically. In either case, it doesn’t allow us to see the situation clearly. Catching ourselves in Cognitive Distortion will help modify our thinking in a way that calms our mind.
YOU’VE ARRIVED! Congratulations! You’ve gotten to the other side of your stressful situation. If you map this same route every time, you’ll be able to navigate any stressful situation that comes your way. \n\n What do you think of this action plan? Don’t worry if you aren’t sure of how to “drive” this path yet. This is why we are learning the skills one step at a time.
Quiz The anxiety cycle quiz Stress and anxiety quiz please indicate how much each statement applied to you over the past week: It can be hard to clearly identify specific fears that trigger our anxiety cycles. In time, you’ll be able to quickly recognize and avoid them. To learn this skill, let’s walk through a series of questions together that will teach you to recognize, identify and understand your anxiety. 1. Recognize the stressful situation(s): Over the last 30 days, have you been affected by the following problems? Work related stress Personal health stressbe Family related stress Social relations stress Acute/chronic stress 2. Identify your response Push Away/Avoidance (“I avoid stressful situations and people at any cost.”) Push Through (“I try to ignore and push through stress.”) Denial (“I either stay positive and push through or shutdown.”) 3. Understand the consequences of your response: What happens to your anxiety as a result? I end up giving up, rejecting, avoiding, and possibly losing important parts of my life, such as relationships, work, grades, time, and health. I ignore stress, get overly productive, multitask, keep myself way too busy, get restless and seek quick relief from stress by unhelpful coping habits. Sometimes I get sick or injured. I have a hard time acknowledging my own stress and anxiety. I also have a hard time following through with changes in order to manage stress, and end up in a vicious cycle of anxiety. Submit Let\'s make a plan Mindfulness - what is it?
Recognize a cycle of anxiety Earlier, we compared facing stressful situations to planning a route to a destination. When the correct steps are taken, there is a beginning and there is an end to the anxiety. Getting caught in the cycle Unfortunately, instead of approaching our stress in this linear way, we often get stuck in a vicious circle: a cycle of anxiety! How does this cycle start? By excessively worrying about a potential threat that hasn’t occurred yet. In addition to worrying about this potential threat, our biased thinking may make us assume that this future event will have a negative outcome. We start to pay more and more attention to possible signs that this negative outcome is likely. Once we have convinced ourselves of this, we look internally to see whether or not we’ll be able to cope with these potential threats. Our anxious symptoms begin to manifest themselves, confirming our suspicions that we won’t be able to cope, which in turn make us more anxious. We have now fully entered a cycle of anxiety! Recognize that everyone is different The truth is that not everyone feels stressed by the same things! By recognizing your personal fears and responses, you’ll be able to avoid falling into the cycle. Let’s examine the responses of Nora, Austin and Melanie to deepen our understanding of this cycle. See if you can identify where Nora, Austin and Melanie enter this cycle, and note how each person’s point of entry is unique. After reading each person’s response, click on the button to highlight the fear that makes them victims of the cycle of anxiety.
My personal health causes me anxiety. In order for me to reduce the risk of a health emergency I can’t afford, I’ll need to work full time, and that will require me to pick up new skills in order to meet higher expectations.” “I avoid and escape from stressful situations. That’s why I quit my job. Because of my health problem, I don’t think I have enough strength to handle pressure. I also keep thinking about how I failed at my first job.” Nora worries so much about her health that she loses more and more confidence about being able to cope successfully. “My work-family balance causes me stress. I’m self-employed and my family thinks I can make time for them while I’m working. I’m constantly multi-tasking, trying to meet everyone’s expectations.” “I’m constantly trying to push myself so I won’t fail in all my tasks and responsibilities. I escape from this pressure by drinking and watching games at night.” Austin takes on additional pressures, using anxiety as a booster to push himself harder. His family complains that he’s checked out in the evenings.
“At first, I had a hard time identifying what makes me anxious because I thought I’ve always managed to keep my head above water by just staying busy and staying positive. But I’m constantly overscheduling myself, mostly to keep up with kids, friends, and family events. My friends tell me I’m pushing myself too hard, but I can’t actually recognize when I’m doing that.” “I’m not aware of it. I’m a bit in denial because I don’t know what normal life looks like. I tend to think everything is fine.” Melanie is often confused and second guessing her feelings. She’s constantly asking others if they are happy and tends to do things in excess.
Stressful situation Consequences Response to stress Nora Austin
Melanie HOW ABOUT YOU? Can you identify the specific fears that could cause you to enter the vicious cycle of anxiety? In the next lesson, answer a few helpful questions that will guide you toward recognizing these fears and avoiding this dangerous cycle.
Battling anxiety can sometimes feel like frantically trying to find the leak in a boat that’s sinking. You know it’s happening but you can’t figure out where and how to make it stop. Understanding where anxiety hides in your mind and body is the key to maintaining your mental health! You’re not alone!
You may think that talking about anxiety is counterproductive and will only make you more anxious. But in reality, the opposite is true! Understanding anxiety gives you control over your emotions. When we don’t understand it, we end up passively accepting other people’s opinions about our anxious responses:
\"You’re too sensitive and emotional!\" \n \"You worry too much!\" \n \"You just need to work less and you’ll be fine.\" Have you heard similar things from friends, family or coworkers?
You can’t control what other people say to you, but you can control how you react to it and what you believe about yourself.
Anxiety is the result of experiencing both minor and major stress. Stress is how we react when we feel pressure or threatened. The first step toward controlling our anxiety is to realize that reactions to stress are different for each of us. If someone judges our reaction to stress, learning to recognize that each person is different will stop us from feeling like we are deficient or weaker than others. Rest assured that those persons react to stress in other ways that you may not!
What are some signs of anxiety that we can start to pay attention to? Some of us react with strong emotions. Our minds may feel out of control.. like a storm of fear, excessive worry and nervousness. We might be caught in a cycle of overthinking, rumination and imagining the worst case scenario.
For others, anxiety shows up in our body. We might experience sweating, headache, chest or stomach pain and hyperventilation.
It could also express itself in our behaviors,such as the way we eat, drink or get trapped in addiction.
Let’s first take a look at your unique signs of anxiety. Like knowing the potentially leaky parts of a boat. Identifying your signs of anxiety will help you control them before they escalate into something worse.
The following quiz will help you get a big picture of how anxiety might be affecting your health and will help you communicate your conditions to others in a more productive way. All or nothing (black and white) thinking
Though worry is a normal and helpful response, it can interfere with our ability to go about our daily lives. It can occur at any time or place, often without us being aware of its exact triggers. A strategy to deal with this problem is to postpone our worry to a specific period of time. This provides our mind with reassurance, just as a loving parent might reassure their child by saying: “Don’t worry, we’ll listen and talk about your worries when you come home. For now, just go have fun at school.” How to do it 1. Create a worry period My Plan
\n • Choose a specific time, place and length of time for worrying \n \n • The time, place and duration should be the same each day \n \n • Make sure the place is comfortable and free from distractions. If possible, always use the same place for your worry period. 2. Postpone your worry Let’s learn a technique to create more balance in how much you are allowing your worry to affect your nervous system. The goal is to use worry in a healthy way by making smart decisions to avoid potential dangers without letting that worry dominate you!
• As soon as you become of aware of a worry, postpone it to the worry period \n \n • In a few words, note your worry in a small notebook or on your phone \n \n • Remind yourself that you will have time to think about it later! \n \n • Tell yourself: \n “No need to worry about it now. I’ll be in a better position to worry in the worry period. There are more important or pleasant things to tend to right now than thinking about my worries.”
• Take a deep breath and, if needed, do one of the body calming exercises \n \n • Re-focus on what’s the most important, best and practical thing you can do for yourself in the moment \n \n • Take immediate action to do something that is either practical, positive, pleasant or active 3. Come back to your worries during the designated worry period When your worry period arrives, settle down in the place you planned and take some time to reflect on the worries you wrote down. Remember the following points:
\n • Only worry about the thing you took note of, and only if you still feel you must \n \n • If all or some of the worries you wrote down are no longer bothering you or no longer seem relevant to you, no further action is required. \n \n • If you do need to worry about some of them, spend no longer than the set amount of time you specified for your worry period. It might also be helpful to write your thoughts down on paper rather than worrying about them in your mind. Later on in this journey, you will learn more specific ways to deal with your worries. For now, just focus on the process of postponing your worries throughout the day and only worrying at a specific time of the day. By doing this, you’ll be setting healthy boundaries between you and your worries! At first, setting these boundaries may seem like a strange thing to do. Like any new skill, it will feel difficult and awkward at the beginning. But with time and practice, what starts out as a formality will turn into something intuitive and natural. Many people predict that they won’t be able to postpone their worry. But in reality, most people are surprised at their ability to do so and end up experiencing a greater sense of control over their anxieties!
There are many examples of biased thinking. As you read through the following examples, you might recognize some thinking patterns and styles that you consistently use. Some of the ideas might sound similar to each other. They aren’t meant to be distinct categories, but rather a range of thinking patterns and styles that you might relate to. All or nothing (black and white) thinking Catastrophizing Perfectionist thinking Negative (mental) filtering Personalization and blame Jumping to conclusions Making negative assumptions Emotional reasoning (“fear talk”) • You have a fixed standard to how you want to proceed with tasks, relationships and problem solving. \n \n • You have expectations of how it “should” turn out. If it doesn’t turn out like you think, you judge yourself to be a failure or as someone who didn’t work hard enough to succeed. \n \n • You judge your own performance, relationships and decisions as either totally good or totally bad. \n \n • Your evaluation of yourself and others tends to be black and white, making it hard to see matters in shades of gray.
• You have a fixed standard to how you want to proceed with tasks, relationships and problem solving. \n \n • You think of exaggerated negative consequences of events or decisions. \n \n • You think that the worst possible outcome will occur if one thing fails. For example: \n \n “If I fail in this test, I will be a total failure in life” \n “If he leaves me, I will never find anyone else” \n “I’ll be unhappy for the rest of my life” \n \n • This thinking leads to unnecessary increases in levels of anxiety and can lean to “acting out” or other unhelpful behaviors. • You have a tendency to demand an extremely high or even flawless level of performance from yourself or others, even when your expectations are in excess of what is required of the situation(ex. cleaning, organizing your closet, etc…) \n \n • This thinking is different from being a high achiever because your expectations are motivated by fear or are paralyzed by the idea of failure (vs. motivated by doing your best). \n \n • Your expectations make you feel anxious, fearful and like you are losing control. \n \n • This thinking often leads to procrastination, self-criticism/judgment or OCD. • You only see one side of a situation (usually the negative side), and you dwell on it obsessively. \n \n • You tend to dismiss positive experiences while amplifying negative ones: \n \n “My work meeting didn’t go well because I forgot to mention something that I prepared.” \n \n “My husband didn’t like what I said at the restaurant. It was such a bad night.” • You believe you are responsible for things that are actually outside your control and feel guilty or ashamed for not being able to control or prevent them. \n \n • This thinking involves self-criticism and judgment: \n \n “I should have tried harder or done better”...when the problem was mutual (ex. relationship breakup, being laid off from work)“ \n \n "I should help out more”... when you see someone struggling. \n• Taking an event or situation and making it about you when it has nothing to do with you: \n “They must be talking about me” ...when someone simply had a private conversation with someone else. • You jump to conclusions with little to no information or facts. \n \n • You quickly label yourself or others by one negative factor: \n \n “I don’t have much to contribute to the conversation, so I KNOW I’m going to look stupid.” \n \n “They stopped talking when I walked in. They were talking about me.” \n \n • This thinking unnecessarily upsets you emotionally because you believe that the conclusions and judgments you made are true. • This is similar to jumping to conclusions, but you have written a “negative script” in your mind without the possibility that it may be incorrect. \n \n • You have strong negative feelings about tasks or relationships because they have happened to you before. \n \n • Mind reading \n \n • You prophesy what’s going to happen, and you either make statements based on your predictions or feel negative about them. • You create “emotional truth” (assumptions) based on your strong feelings (especially fear) on matters: \n \n “I feel guilty so I must have done something bad.” \n \n “Something bad is going to happen because I strongly feel fear.” \n \n • Although you think you are reasoning logically, you are allowing your strong emotions to lead you to a skewed view of reality. What do you think? \nDo you recognize any of these thinking patterns in yourself? Hopefully, you can now recognize how holding on to biased thinking is detrimental to your emotional wellbeing. It’s time to add warm sunlight to your biased thinking! Think of yourself as your own best friend... reasonable and kind. The following exercise will help you go through the motions of catching and correcting your thoughts so you can be more like the Sun and less like the North Wind. 1. Pick a situation Under what circumstances can you catch yourself holding onto one of the examples of biased thinking? \n \nThink of one specific situation where you always hold yourself to a fixed, rigid standard. Is it usually about.. Money Job security or performance Study Relationships Health Traveling (airplane, driving) Parenting Time management or appointments Public speaking Pets Other 2. Choose one example of biased thinking you identify with Review the types of biased thinking All or nothing (black and white) thinking (pop up description for each one) Making negative assumptions (fortune telling) 3. Based on the type of biased thinking you’ve chosen, write one or two thoughts, beliefs or reactions you might typically have in your specific situation: Save it to weekly summary journal entry Rate yourself: How strongly do you feel that the thoughts or beliefs you listed above are true? 1: I know they’re not true 5: I strongly believe them to be true 5. Evaluate your thoughts: Even though your biased thinking sounds logical, why isn’t it necessarily realistic? Can you come up with three reasons why your thoughts or beliefs may not be completely true? \n If you have a hard time coming up with reasons why your thinking may not be realistic, think about the following questions: . “What are the consequences of my thinking and beliefs?” . “How does my thinking feed my anxiety and worry?” Evidence 1 Evidence 2 Evidence 3 Make sure to fill out three of your own reasons before moving to the next step.
Our window of tolerance Hyper-arousal Making a plan Have you ever filled a party balloon with air? If so, you’ll know what it feels like as the balloon stretches and stretches until it can’t stretch any further. Any more air.... and it pops! Similarly, our bodies have an optimal emotional range where it functions best. We call this our “Window of Tolerance”. When we are in our Window of Tolerance, we feel like we can deal with whatever’s happening in our life. We might feel stress or pressure, but it doesn’t bother us too much. This is the ideal place to be. But when we are under stress, that window becomes very small. It can stretch a bit, but if our stressors are greater than our window, we will fall outside into one of two opposite states: Anxiety, fear, irritation, panic. You might experience the “Fight or Flight” response. Emotional numbness, exhaustion, depression, dissociation, withdrawal, lethargy. You might experience your body shutting down or freezing. The good news is that there are exercises that target both states: Mindfulness-what is it? Progressive muscle relaxation Touch and butterfly hug Hand over your heart Mindful walking Mindful dance Mindful running Mindful body movement
Sometimes, seeing anxiety through others’ eyes can help us understand it better. Let’s meet three friends who view and respond to stress differently. Though their personalities and lifestyles are different, you will probably relate to one of them. First, let’s meet Nora. Nora tends to push away and avoid stressful situations. See if you can identify this in the way she expresses herself: “I studied business and marketing at university, but I couldn’t handle the pressure of meeting monthly goals at work. I got sick so I quit, and now I’m working at a coffee shop during the day and have a part time cleaning job at night. My health problems have put a lot of restrictions on my life choices and I can’t enjoy things I used to enjoy. I often stay up late at night thinking about my problems and escape by watching TV. Something needs to change, but I\'m not sure where to begin. I\'m scared my health is not going to get better and this is just going to be my new life.”> Do you relate to some of Nora’s feelings and reactions? Next, let’s meet Austin. Austin believes that pushing through stress is the way to go. Listen to how he feels about his work life: “People tell me that I’m a hard-working and productive person, and it’s true… I can push myself pretty hard. I run my own business and I can multitask all day. I don’t ask others for help because it’s just easier and quicker if I do it all myself. I can’t really trust anyone else to get things done right.\n\n I subconsciously use anxiety to drive myself. I rely on facts, analysis, and information, I don’t think anyone views me as an anxious person.” Do you respond to stressful situations like Austin does? Finally, let’s meet Melanie. She tends to force herself to stay positive, even though doing so can sometimes result in her being in denial about her circumstances: “I care about people so I’m good at helping others in need. I just constantly have a lot on my plate and I’m tired all the time. I try to be on top of my kid’s school and sports events, and enjoy doing special things for my anniversary and family holidays. I’m incredibly busy and often wonder when I get to live my life for myself.\n\n Sometimes I just go into my room and turn on the TV or scroll through social media to shut down because I’m simply exhausted. I love reading positive quotes because I think if I stay positive I can keep going.” Have you ever responded to stress like Melanie does? Information Worry and anxiety are closely related and, in fact, happen in sequence. \n Worry is really about you being “smart”. You worry so that you can avoid or problem-solve potential dangers or negative future events. Anxiety is your response to worry, and that happens in your nervous system. \n \n Normally, worry is short-lived and leads to positive problem-solving. For example, “I worry that I won’t have time to cook dinner tonight and the kids will go to bed hungry” leads to deciding to prepare food ahead of time or ordering takeout on the way home from work. Worrying has led to a smart decision and a successful outcome. \n \n On the other hand, worry becomes unhelpful when we both overestimate the stress of the situation and also believe we don’t have the necessary competency, resiliency or outside resources to face it. What started as worry turns into anxiety and fear. \n \n Let’s learn a technique to create more balance in how much you are allowing your worry to affect your nervous system. The goal is to use worry in a healthy way by making smart decisions to avoid potential dangers without letting that worry dominate you!
After an anxiety attack, it’s common to feel embarrassed and think: “I don’t even recognize myself.” That’s because when we experience anxiety, we often respond in ways that we normally don’t. What we are noticing in retrospect was a behavioral response to anxiety. \n \n These behavioral responses are tricky to identify because we tend to confuse them with our personality traits or natural tendencies. \n \nFor example, would you ever say: “I procrastinate when I’m anxious”? Likely not! When we procrastinate, we usually don’t blame it on anxiety and believe that it’s just part of our nature. \n \nBut in reality, behaviors like procrastination are part of what we call “all or nothing behavior”. It’s an extreme reaction in an effort to find balance, gain control and escape a cycle of anxiety. \n \nThese extreme reactions are either \n \n rigidly controlling things around us (like Austin), or \n \n...disengaging and giving up all control of anything (like Nora). \n \nWe may appear to act in compulsive ways, perhaps over-drinking, over-talking, or obsessively organizing. \n \nConversely, we may disengage by giving up, procrastinating, avoiding others or isolating ourselves. We might start to act in a way that others label as lazy, irresponsible, and even selfish. Dependency on alcohol, substances or tobacco can be a sign that we are trying to find quick relief from anxiety. \n \nIf left unchecked, what are initially behavioral responses to anxiety can become so common that they could become ingrained in our personality in the long run. But don’t worry! You are not alone. You can learn to separate your personality from your behavioral responses to anxiety, and it starts with learning to identify your unique behavioral signs of stress.
Have you noticed that many people automatically fall into rigid and unhelpful styles of thinking? This can happen to us without even being aware of it. Unfortunately, when this becomes a constant and consistent habit, these rigid styles of thinking become the cause of emotional distress. Worries and anxieties are contagious. Even just being around a person who thinks in a rigid way and tends to guide their behavior through many rules can cause you to experience anxiety. \n \n First, let’s bring these rigid and automatic types of thinking into awareness by learning how they can trigger our emotions and behaviors. If you’ve come this far, you’re doing great! So far, we’ve learned skills to calm our anxious body. Now let’s identify unhelpful self-statements and thoughts that can feed our worries and anxieties.
Research has shown that exercise improves cell health and boosts the brain’s natural anti-anxiety drug. How so? Harvard medical school studies show that exercise diverts our minds from the very things we are anxious about. Moving our bodies decreases muscle tension, lowering our body’s contribution to feeling anxious. Increasing our heart rate actively changes our brain chemistry, increasing the availability of important anti-anxiety neurochemicals such as serotonin and GABA. Exercise also activates our brain’s frontal lobe, helping control the reacting system located in the amygdala. We all have different health conditions and body types. Which exercise you choose is up to you! Even general physical activity, such as walking, cleaning and taking care of animals is helpful. To maximize its benefits, choose something enjoyable so you will be more likely to repeat it. You’ll build resilience little by little. Work steadily toward increasing your heart rate. Working out with a friend or in a group brings the added benefit of social support. If possible, exercise in nature or in a greenspace. This will further lower stress and anxiety levels. The most important thing is to do it! Do you have some time today to get started?

What are the benefits of mindful walking? 1.Stress Reduction: Engaging in mindful walking can be an effective way to reduce stress and promote relaxation. By directing your attention to the physical sensations of walking, you create a mental break from everyday stressors. This practice activates the relaxation response in your body, leading to a calmer state of mind.\n 2.Emotional Regulation: Engaging in mindful walking can help regulate your emotions. By observing your thoughts and emotions as they arise during the practice, you develop a non-judgmental and accepting attitude towards them. This can enhance emotional resilience and provide you with a greater sense of control over your reactions to challenging situations. Adrenaline Adrenaline, also known as epinephrine, is a hormone and neurotransmitter produced by the adrenal glands, which are located on top of the kidneys. It plays a crucial role in the body\'s response to stress and triggering the \"Fight or Flight\" response.\n When a person perceives a threat or danger, whether real or perceived, the brain signals the adrenal glands to release adrenaline into the bloodstream. Adrenaline acts as a chemical messenger, rapidly preparing the body for action to deal with the perceived threat. Anxiety attack The term "anxiety attack" is not officially recognized in the diagnostic manuals; DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders). It is often used to describe a period of heightened anxiety or a more prolonged state of anxiousness. Anxiety attacks may involve similar symptoms to panic attacks, such as excessive worry, restlessness, irritability, muscle tension, difficulty concentrating, and sleep disturbances. Automatic thinking Automatic thinking refers to the rapid, involuntary, and often unconscious thoughts that arise in response to situations or triggers. These thoughts are automatic in the sense that they occur automatically and effortlessly, without deliberate intention or conscious awareness.\n Automatic thinking patterns can be influenced by past experiences, beliefs, and cognitive biases. They can be helpful or unhelpful, depending on their content and impact on emotions and behaviors. In the context of anxiety, automatic thoughts often lean towards negative and worrisome interpretations of situations, leading to increased anxiety and distress. Biased thinking Biased thinking refers to cognitive distortions or errors in thinking that influence how we perceive and interpret information. It involves a tendency to view situations, events, or ourselves in a distorted or exaggerated manner, often leading to negative or irrational thoughts. Biased thinking can contribute to the development and maintenance of anxiety and other mental health issues. Cortisol Cortisol is a hormone produced by the adrenal glands in response to stress. It is often referred to as the primary stress hormone. When the brain detects a threat or perceives stress, it signals the release of cortisol into the bloodstream. While cortisol is important for short-term stress adaptation, chronic or prolonged elevation of cortisol levels due to chronic stress can cause a loss of neurons in the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus. It also decreases serotonin, the “happy hormone”, which makes a person feel angry, depressed, and feel physical pain more quickly and easily. Cognitive distortion Cognitive distortions, also known as biased thinking or irrational thoughts, refer to exaggerated or irrational patterns of thinking that can contribute to emotional distress and maintain anxiety or other mental health issues.\n Cognitive distortions are common and can affect the way individuals interpret and perceive events, situations, and themselves. They often involve biases or errors in reasoning that lead to distorted or negative thinking patterns. Competency Competency refers to the ability to perform or execute a task or set of skills effectively. It is often associated with knowledge, expertise, and proficiency in a particular area. Competency is measured by evaluating our aptitude, qualifications, or capabilities in a specific situation. Compulsive behaviour Compulsive behavior refers to repetitive and often ritualistic actions or thoughts that individuals feel driven to perform in response to anxiety or distressing thoughts. These behaviors are typically aimed at reducing anxiety, preventing perceived harm, or maintaining a sense of control. However, they are often excessive, time-consuming, and interfere with daily functioning. Dependency Dependency refers to reliance on substances such as alcohol, drugs, or tobacco as a means of coping with anxiety or seeking quick relief or escape from anxiety or help coping with overwhelming emotions. However, substance dependency can be problematic and can lead to long-term physical, psychological, and social consequences. GABA GABA stands for gamma-aminobutyric acid, which is a neurotransmitter in the brain. It is known as the brains natural anti-anxiety drug because it has inhibitory effects on the central nervous system, helping to reduce neuronal excitability and promote relaxation.GABA acts as a calming agent, counteracting the effects of excitatory neurotransmitters in the brain.\n By increasing GABA levels through exercise, individuals may experience a reduction in anxiety symptoms, improved mood, and an overall sense of well-being. This is one of the ways in which exercise can have a positive impact on mental health and help alleviate anxiety. Hyperventilation Hyperventilation refers to a rapid or excessive increase in breathing rate and volume. It involves taking in more oxygen and exhaling more carbon dioxide than the body needs. Hyperventilation can be a physiological response to anxiety or stress and is often associated with panic attacks. Mindful breathing Mindful breathing is a technique that involves intentionally bringing awareness to the breath and focusing on the present moment. It is a fundamental practice in mindfulness and can help promote relaxation, reduce stress, and cultivate a sense of calm. Obsession Obsession refers to intrusive, persistent, and unwanted thoughts, images, or urges that repeatedly and uncontrollably enter a persons mind. Individuals with obsessions often recognize that their thoughts are irrational or excessive, but they find it challenging to dismiss or ignore them. As a result, they may engage in various repetitive behaviors or mental rituals, known as compulsions, to alleviate the anxiety caused by the obsessions temporarily. Panic attack A panic attack is a sudden and intense episode of fear or discomfort that typically peaks within minutes. It is a manifestation of anxiety and can occur without any apparent trigger or in response to a specific situation or object. Panic attacks can be accompanied by various physical and psychological symptoms, such as a rapid heart rate, chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, trembling, sweating, a sense of impending doom or loss of control, and feelings of unreality or detachment. Progressive muscle relaxation Progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) is a relaxation technique that involves systematically tensing and relaxing different muscle groups in the body. It aims to reduce muscle tension, release physical stress, and promote overall relaxation. Resilience Resilience refers to the capacity to bounce back, adapt, and recover in the face of adversity, challenges, or stressful situations. It is the ability to withstand, cope with, and effectively navigate through difficulties, setbacks, or hardships. Resilience involves psychological, emotional, and sometimes physical strength to maintain a positive mindset and being able to function despite adversity.\n Resilience is not about avoiding or eliminating challenges, but rather about how we respond and recover from them. It involves skills such as emotional regulation, problem-solving, flexibility, optimism, and social support. Resilience helps us persevere, learn from setbacks, and grow stronger as a result. Rigid thinking Rigid thinking refers to inflexible and narrow patterns of thinking that limit flexibility, adaptability, and open-mindedness. People with rigid thinking tend to adhere strictly to their beliefs, rules, and expectations without considering alternative perspectives or possibilities. They may have a black-and-white view of the world, categorizing things as either all good or all bad, with little room for shades of gray or ambiguity.\n When faced with challenges or uncertainties, individuals with rigid thinking may become overwhelmed or stuck, as they struggle to adapt and find alternative solutions. Rigid thinking can also lead to self-criticism, perfectionism, and a constant need for control, which can perpetuate anxiety and stress. Rumination The tendency to continuously and excessively think about negative events, situations, or problems. It involves repetitively focusing on ones distressing thoughts, often with a lack of resolution or progress toward a solution.\n Rumination is a common cognitive process associated with anxiety and other mental health conditions. When someone ruminates, they may replay past events, worry about future outcomes, or excessively analyze their thoughts and feelings. This prolonged dwelling on negative thoughts can contribute to heightened anxiety and a sense of feeling stuck or trapped in ones worries Self-compassion Self-compassion refers to the practice of treating oneself with kindness, understanding, and non-judgment during times of difficulty, failure, or suffering. It involves extending the same warmth, care, and support to oneself that one would offer to a close friend or loved one who is struggling. Serotonin Serotonin is a neurotransmitter, a chemical messenger in the brain and nervous system that plays a crucial role in regulating various physiological and psychological processes. It is often referred to as the "feel-good" neurotransmitter because of its association with mood regulation and feelings of well-being. Window of tolerance Window of tolerance refers to a concept in psychology that describes an optimal range of arousal or activation that allows an individual to effectively cope with and respond to stressors and emotions. The window of tolerance suggests that individuals have a range in which they can handle and adapt to stressors without becoming overwhelmed or shutting down. When a person is within their window of tolerance, they are able to think clearly, make rational decisions, and engage in effective problem-solving. They are also able to experience and regulate emotions in a balanced and healthy manner.

Stressful situation Consequences Response to stress
1. I found myself getting upset by minor things.
2. I was aware of dryness of my mouth.
3. I experienced breathing difficulty (e.g., excessively rapid breathing).
4. I tended to overreact to situations.
5. I had a feeling of shakiness, like my legs were going to give way.
6. I found myself getting upset rather easily.
7. I found myself getting impatient when I was delayed in any way, like by elevators, traffic lights, or people who kept me waiting.
8. I perspired noticeably, like with sweaty palms, even when I wasnt doing anything physical.
9. I felt scared without any good reason.
10. I was aware of my heart rate, even when I wasnt doing anything physical.
11. I found that I was very irritable.
12. I felt I was close to panic.
13. I found it hard to calm down after something upset me.
14. I found it difficult to tolerate interruptions to what I was doing.
15. I was in a state of nervous tension with what I was doing.
16. I was worried about situations in which I might panic and make a fool of myself.

Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree, or a good part of time

//review thinks dialog text • You have a fixed standard to how you want to proceed with tasks, relationships and problem solving. \n \n • You have expectations of how it “should” turn out. If it doesn’t turn out like you think, you judge yourself to be a failure or as someone who didn’t work hard enough to succeed. \n \n • You judge your own performance, relationships and decisions as either totally good or totally bad. \n \n • Your evaluation of yourself and others tends to be black and white, making it hard to see matters in shades of gray.
• You often see things as a catastrophe, which means a “complete disaster”. \n \n • You think of exaggerated negative consequences of events or decisions. \n \n • You think that the worst possible outcome will occur if one thing fails. For example: \n \n “If I fail in this test, I will be a total failure in life” “If he leaves me, I will never find anyone else” “I’ll be unhappy for the rest of my life” .This thinking leads to unnecessary increases in levels of anxiety and can lean to “acting out” or other unhelpful behaviors. • You have a tendency to demand an extremely high or even flawless level of performance from yourself or others, even when your expectations are in excess of what is required of the situation(ex. cleaning, organizing your closet, etc..) \n \n • This thinking is different from being a high achiever because your expectations are motivated by fear or are paralyzed by the idea of failure (vs. motivated by doing your best). \n \n • Your expectations make you feel anxious, fearful and like you are losing control. \n \n • This thinking often leads to procrastination, self-criticism/judgment or OCD. • You only see one side of a situation (usually the negative side), and you dwell on it obsessively. \n \n • You tend to dismiss positive experiences while amplifying negative ones: \n \n “My work meeting didn’t go well because I forgot to mention something that I prepared.” \n \n “My husband didn’t like what I said at the restaurant. It was such a bad night.” • You believe you are responsible for things that are actually outside your control and feel guilty or ashamed for not being able to control or prevent them. \n \n • This thinking involves self-criticism and judgment: \n \n “I should have tried harder or done better” ..when the problem was mutual (ex. relationship breakup, being laid off from work) \n \n “I should help out more” ..when you see someone struggling. \n \n • Taking an event or situation and making it about you when it has nothing to do with you \n \n • “They must be talking about me” ..when someone simply had a private conversation with someone else.
• You jump to conclusions with little to no information or facts. \n \n • You quickly label yourself or others by one negative factor: \n \n “I don’t have much to contribute to the conversation, so I KNOW I’m going to look stupid.” \n \n “They stopped talking when I walked in. They were talking about me.” \n \n • This thinking unnecessarily upsets you emotionally because you believe that the conclusions and judgments you made are true. • This is similar to jumping to conclusions, but you have written a “negative script” in your mind without the possibility that it may be incorrect. \n \n • You have strong negative feelings about tasks or relationships because they have happened to you before. \n \n • Mind reading \n \n • You prophesy what’s going to happen, and you either make statements based on your predictions or feel negative about them. • You create “emotional truth” (assumptions) based on your strong feelings (especially fear) on matters: \n \n “I feel guilty so I must have done something bad.” \n \n “Something bad is going to happen because I strongly feel fear.” \n \n • Although you think you are reasoning logically, you are allowing your strong emotions to lead you to a skewed view of reality. 7. Rate yourself again: Now that you’ve adjusted your biased thinking, how strongly do you feel that the thoughts or beliefs you listed above are true? If your rating has remained at four or five, try this exercise again. The goal is to reach a rating of one. If you find it hard to reach a lower rating, try applying it to different scenarios and situations until you learn to step away from biased thinking. If you are still having a hard time modifying your thinking, you might ask someone you trust to help you through this exercise. It’s important to keep practicing using this format because you don’t always realize when you’re using biased thinking in your day-to-day life. The more you practice, the more you’ll be aware of it, and the easier it will be to catch and modify it as you face daily circumstances. You’ll also start recognizing biased thinking in other people.\n There will be times when people communicate with you using their own biased thinking, which you might believe to be the definite truth. Many times, someone else’s biased thinking may trigger your own. If you can master the ability to recognize it, you’ll not only avoid unhelpful behavior, but you may also help others think and act in more positive and productive ways.
//expand adapter restructed All or nothing Why isn’t the idea of "setting up a fixed standard of how you do things" realistic? \n \nExample: \n \nMost tasks can’t be measured as just "good" or "bad" (there is a measure of progress). \n \nEven if I try hard, other factors can affect my performance (e.g., difficult clients, exams harder than usual, unfavorable weather). \n\nThere were times when others commended me for a job well done, but I felt I could’ve done better. Why isn\'t the idea of \“the worst possible outcome will occur if one thing fails\” realistic?\n\nExample:\n\nMost of the things that people worry about never actually happen.\n\nSuccessful people also experience setbacks \n(ex. failing in exam), but they still manage to find a way to be successful. (ex. finding a job)\n\nSometimes it\'s the \“fear\” that social media or others create, but it\'s up to me to believe it or not.
Why isn’t the idea of "believing your responsible for things that are outside of your control" realistic?\n\nExample:\n\n We all tend to think of ourselves and forget the other persons needs and circumstances without bad intention.\n\n Humans are limited with control (no one has enough power to control unpleasant situations), therefore it’s not necessary "I" failed in fixing it.\n\n People have their own feelings and needs so what I think should be their needs can be different from what they actually need. They are held accountable to figure it out for themselves.\n\n There may be a reason that I don’t know explaining why people didn’t include me, but it doesn’t mean they intentionally excluded me.\n\n There are other factors involved in other people’s behaviors besides me.\n
Why isn’t the idea of “jumping to conclusions with little to no facts” realistic?\n\nExample:\n\n Many times, my “worries” make me jump to conclusions because I don’t want to get hurt.\n\n Just because it happened once before, it’s not reasonable to assume it will always be that way. (ex. people cheating, rejection, lies etc.)\n\n Telling myself the worst-case scenario or being judgmental is not really a kind way of protecting myself, rather it will take me to a twisted way of viewing people, situations, and the world.\n
Why isn’t the idea of “writing a negative script in your mind” why isn\’t it realistic?\n\n Example:\n\n Many times, this occurs because people grow up in a family where honest communication rarely existed and I was unable to express my honest feelings. But it’s not fair to assume that everyone grew up the same way I did.\n\n If I have the right support, there is always a way to resolve negative situations, therefore I don’t have to be overly worried about what’s going to happen.\n\n There were times I really thought that a certain thing would occur, but in the end, it turned out completely different or it never happened.\n
Why isn’t the idea of “emotional reasoning based on your strong fears” realistic?\n\nExample:\n\n Many times, “worries” make me jump to conclusions because I don’t want to get hurt.\n\n Just because it happened once before, it’s not reasonable to assume it will always be that way. (ex. people cheating, rejection, lies etc.)\n\n Telling myself the worst-case scenario or being judgmental is not really a kind way of protecting myself, rather it will take me to a twisted way of viewing people, situations, and the world.\n
Why isn’t the idea of “expect to perform at the highest level” realistic?\n\nExample:\n\nIn reality, being perfect is not the way to get what I need; appreciation, love, approval.\n\nIt\'s possible to grow and mature, but it\'s impossible to become perfect.\n\nJust because it didn\'t turn out the way I wanted to, it\'s not all bad.\nIt\'s my internal voice telling me to set a high standard, no one is expecting it from me.\n\nIf I overly focus on the result, I would be dismissing the efforts and enjoyment in process. Why isn’t the idea of “excessively dwelling on the negative aspects” realistic?\n\nExample:\n\nWe are all imperfect and there is no one who never makes a mistake.\n\nIt\'s up to me to learn from my mistakes or let them bring me down. It depends on how I look at it.\n\nIt\'s my critical mind that is focusing on the negatives and in reality, the actual experiences are not all negative.

Now that we’ve discussed what biased thinking is, let’s connect the dots! How exactly does biased thinking affect the way we feel, which in turn affects the way we behave?\n\n Listen to the tale of “The north wind and the sun”: Let’s imagine that the north wind represents biased thinking and that the sun represents self-compassion. Which one do you think is most effective in guiding our behavior? Biased thinking can be logical and true, but when it becomes too rigid and lacking in self-compassion, the result is defensive behavior, just like the traveler. Read the following thoughts from Nora and Melanie, and see if you can identify how biased thinking skews their ability to evaluate their respective situations clearly: “I was in a pretty intense work environment, having to meet monthly goals. When I started making up bunch of internal rules and standards in my mind and talking to myself like a judgmental friend my anxiety spiked. I began to feel inadequate and I quit” 1. Which biased thinkings does she have? All or nothing thinking Perfectionism thinking Making negative assumptions 2. How has her biased thinking triggered her emotion? Sad Anxiety Inadequacy Anger That\'s right! Let\'s try again “I was in a pretty intense work environment, having to meet monthly goals. When I started making up bunch of internal rules and standards in my mind and talking to myself like a judgmental friend my anxiety spiked. I began to feel inadequate and I quit” “I always thought that if I stay positive, everything will be fine and that it’s my job to make everyone happy. I have to admit there were plenty of moments that I was driven by fear and anxiety to make everyone happy, and I overscheduled myself. It got me into an ‘overdrive-crash’ lifestyle cycle” Personalization and blame Fear It’s important to understand the role that biased thinking plays in excessive, irrational worry and persistent anxiety. Biased thinking can happen to any of us! The goal is to catch ourselves and modify our thinking before it starts to create intense anxiety.\n\n Let’s do an exercise that will help you fine tune your ability to make the connection between your thoughts and feelings and your actions. Check which reactions you most identify with. Scenario 1 You came to work on Monday and unexpectedly found troubling emails from clients. I might think (biased thinking): Negative assumptions: \n “There is no way I can resolve it by the end of the day. I’ve already failed.” Jumping to conclusions: \n “They are upset and I’m in trouble.” Perfectionism:\n “I need to think every single mistakes I possible made to cause this trouble first, otherwise I can’t respond back to them” Catastrophizing:\n “If I don’t get back to them today, I’ll lose my clients and will be in trouble with my boss.” I might feel: Incompetent Disappointed Shame Fear (afraid of challenges and failing) Nervous Pressure Overwhelmed Agitated Frustrated Angry Judgmental Hopeless/Helpless Bad mood Numb Saved Depressed I might (behavior): ..use the phrases “should”, “have to” and “must” are running through my mind ..procrastinate in responding to emails ..skip taking a break and lunch and not talk to anyone at work all day ..have a panic attack ..get discouraged before even trying ..have negative thoughts and beliefs that snowball and spiral, and there will be no room to change it ..forecast what’s going to happen and make decisions based on it ..have lots of negative and fear talk ..overly generalize matters: “I’ll never get better”, “It’s always like this”... ..isolate myself or shut down, feeling hopeless because I have no way to avoid the idea of worst-case scenario There is no right or wrong answers.\nThis exercise help connect\nthe thinking with the action. You came to a party and started to get overwhelmed because very few people interacted with you. Scenario 2 All or nothing:\n “It was a bad idea to come to this party.” Fear talk: \n “I’ve been rejected. I might have done or said something bad.” Negative filtering:\n “I’m boring and no one wants to talk to me.” Personalization and blame: \n “They didn’t really come talk to me. They didn’t want me to come (maybe I’m not fun enough).” ...try to excessively fix situations or relationships ...ruminate over things I said or did wrong ...feel insecure and inadequate in that social setting. I will be afraid of making mistakes in public. ...have difficulty receiving constructive criticism or feedback because I will dwell on the negative side of it and dismiss the positives Try to excessively help out or talk to entertain friends Excessively observe people\'s facial expressions, behaviors and reaction to read their mind Leave the party right away All or nothing Emotions: Behaviors: Quitting work This is your report \nTittle: Biased thinkings Thoughts: Perfectionism Were any of these reactions familiar to you? Learning to identify them early o will help you avoid the trap of biases thinking! But what can you do about it once you’ve identified it ? Rigid biased thinkings Fear talk Painful emotions Unhelpful coping skills/behaviors Trigger motivates
\n“You should get eight hours of sleep!” Regardless of how many hours of sleep we should technically get, it remains an important but elusive part of our day. Few people understand why sleep is so important when it comes to anxiety management. \nSleep deprivation causes insulin resistance \nStudies show that one third of Americans have insulin resistance, resulting in a reduced ability to adapt to stress and stimulate chronic stress hormones. This, in turn, results in increased anxiety and depression. Researchers have found that during sleep, the glymphatic system (our body’s waste removal system, part of the nervous system) was ten times more active than while it was awake. In other words, our brain goes through a detoxification process while we are sleeping. When completed properly, we wake up with a clearer head and a more alert mind. \nHere are some tips to improve your sleep: \n1. Try not to depend on artificial stimulation to help keep you awake. Highly refined foods, excessive caffeine and adrenaline producing activities lead to chronic sleep deprivation. Because you’re not getting enough sleep, your brain comes to believe that you are fine without it! \n \n2. Create a sleep-conducive environment by reducing the level of brightness where you sleep. Intentionally turning lights way down about an hour before bedtime helps create more melatonin in your system. You can also design your bedroom to support quality sleep by using black out and sound baffling drapes to keep it dark and quiet. \n \n3. Stick to a regular sleep schedule: go to bed and get up at about the same time every day of the week. \n \n4. It’s OK to use sedating supplements such as chamomile, theanine, GABA and melatonin as long as they are used occasionally, in moderation, and as indicated. These are generally more conducive to natural sleep rather than getting “knocked out” by prescription sleeping pills. Did you know? Insulin resistance is when cells in your muscles, fat, and liver don’t respond well to insulin and can’t use glucose from your blood for energy. To make up for it, your pancreas makes more insulin. Over time, your blood sugar levels go up. \nDo you think there are some ways you can start improving your sleep quality?\n\n Sugar lights up the addiction centers in our brains, similar to what happens when someone uses cocaine. This is important to remember, considering that our brain controls our emotions and behaviors Three negative effects that sugar and processed food have on anxiety are:\n\n 1. Insulin resistance (You’ve already learned about this danger in the section on “Anxiety and Sleep”)\n\n 2. Leptin resistance (You can’t feel when you are full at mealtimes)\n\n 3. Increased inflammation in your body (Causes you pains and stress)\n\n As you can imagine, experiencing one or more of these effects produces more anxiety.\n\n\n
How can you determine if you are addicted to sugar and processed food?\n Look for these signs \n\n •Frequent headaches, lethargy, feeling tired, cravings, muscle pain, nausea, bloating, insomnia\n\n •Trying to quit sugar produces headaches or fatigue\n\n •Having a hard time recognizing when you are full or have eaten enough\n\n
Some tips to improve your diet \nThis information does not promote or suggest any specific diet plan. Any intervention in your diet must be balanced and responsible. But here are two things you can do to start on a path toward a healthier diet:\n \n1.Consult with a nutritionist or doctor for recommendations on a specific diet plan tailored to you\n \n2.Try a sugar detox in order to “reset” your body. This will:\n \u00A0\u00A0a.Improve your cells’ sensitivity to insulin\n \u00A0\u00A0b.Reduce cortisol levels\n \u00A0\u00A0c.Lower ghrelin levels (regulates hunger and appetite)\n \u00A0\u00A0d.Improve leptin sensitivity\n \u00A0\u00A0e.Increase dopamine levels naturally\n \u00A0\u00A0f.Reset your taste buds\n \u00A0\u00A0g.Reduce inflammation\n\n Unfortunately, many of us consume more sugar than we are aware of because it’s lurking in so many foods we would never expect to contain it. The average person consumes 152 lbs. (69 kg) of sugar per year! It’s true, sugar is responsible for increased waist lines. But the real problem is addiction. A study by Dr. Serge H. Ahmed (“Is Sugar As Addictive As Cocaine?”) shows that sugar was eight times more addictive than cocaine. Diets such as the “Keto Diet” and Dr. Mark Hyman’s “10-day Detox Diet” are designed to reset your body. When it comes to establishing long-term eating habits, you need to make sure you are doing so in a balanced and reasonable way. Alcohol/Substances Tracking It’s not easy to tolerate anxiety.\n Understandably, many who want to control their anxiety without prescriptions often turn to alcohol or substances: they are easy to acquire and they provide quick relief from stress, rumination and worries. But in the long run, this easy path quickly leads to destructive patterns that can be impossible to escape from without drastic intervention.\n \n Since alcohol and substances are commonly associated with anxiety, we’d like to provide you with information on ways to cope with alcohol and substances. What do you think?\n • 40 million americans suffer from some kind of anxiety disorder at any given time\n • 1 in 5 individuals with anxiety report using alcohol or substance to cope with stress\n • 20% of people diagnosed with alcohol or substance use disorder also suffer from an anxiety or mood disorder\n\n The purpose of learning about the prevalence of alcohol and substance dependence is not to make ourselves feel judged. Understanding it helps us be aware of and avoid the vicious cycle of addiction we can easily find ourselves in when looking for comfort from anxiety. “Stress” and “Anxiety” are two words we hear often in our everyday lives. This is not surprising, because both things are related to each other. Ultimately, they have a direct effect on our behaviors.\n\n Though anxiety is often triggered by fear, both external and internal experiences can trigger stress and anxiety. External experiences could be things like challenging situations or health problems. Internal experiences can be things like negative thoughts, self-criticism, judgements or remembering shameful memories. In either case, understanding your stress can help you manage your anxiety. Learn how to Manage your Anxiety Yes, we’ve all heard it
